Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story:
I sat at my desk, the glow of my monitor casting shadows across the room. My inbox pinged with another code review comment: “Performance issues—please refactor.” I knew the team expected nothing less than clean, efficient code, especially with the new feature launch looming. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, mind racing with possible solutions. But my phone buzzed again—this time, a message from my mother. “Don’t forget, tonight is the family dinner. We’re counting on you to help with the rituals. It’s important to your father and me.” 

I glanced at the clock. The dinner was in an hour, and my code was far from perfect. My family had been talking for weeks about the importance of upholding our traditions, especially now, when everyone seemed so busy and distant. I felt the weight of their expectations pressing on me, the need to honor our values and not let them down. At the same time, the thought of letting my team down gnawed at me. My heart pounded as I stared at the screen, torn between two worlds, each demanding more than I felt I could give.
